_link.title: I can apply the formula P = VI to calculate electrical power

toLevel2.question: In the formula P = VI, what does P represent?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: P represents electrical power, measured in watts. It tells us the rate at which electrical energy is transferred.

toLevel2.question: A device operates at 12 V and draws 2 A. What is its power?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Using P = VI = 12 V × 2 A = 24 W. The device transfers 24 joules of energy per second.

toLevel2.question: What two quantities must you know to calculate electrical power using P = VI?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The formula P = VI requires voltage (potential difference) and current. Multiplying these gives power in watts.

toLevel2.question: A lamp operates at 240 V and 0.25 A. What is its power rating?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: P = VI = 240 × 0.25 = 60 W. This is a standard 60-watt lamp.

toLevel2.question: If power is measured in watts, voltage in volts, and current in amperes, what is 1 watt equivalent to?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: From P = VI, 1 W = 1 V × 1 A. One watt of power is produced when one volt drives one ampere of current.

toLevel2.question: The formula P = VI shows that electrical power equals [[voltage]] multiplied by current.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Power is the product of voltage and current. Higher voltage or higher current both lead to higher power.

toLevel2.question: If a circuit has a voltage of 6 V and a current of 3 A, the power is [[18]] W.
To find the current drawn by a device, rearrange P = VI to get I = [[P/V]].
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Dividing both sides by V gives I = P/V. Current equals power divided by voltage.

toLevel2.question: A 100 W device operating at 10 V draws a current of 10 A.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Using I = P/V = 100/10 = 10 A. The device draws 10 amperes at 10 volts to achieve 100 watts.

toLevel2.question: Doubling the voltage across a device while keeping the current the same will halve the power.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: From P = VI, if V doubles and I stays constant, P doubles. Power is directly proportional to voltage for constant current.

toLevel3.question: A 2400 W heater operates on 240 V mains. What current does it draw?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: I = P/V = 2400/240 = 10 A. The heater draws 10 amperes from the mains supply.

toLevel3.question: A 12 V car battery delivers 60 A to the starter motor. What power is delivered?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: P = VI = 12 × 60 = 720 W. The starter motor receives 720 watts of electrical power.

toLevel3.question: Why does P = VI show that high-voltage devices can achieve the same power with less current?
toLevel3.correctAnswer: For a given power P, increasing V means I must decrease since P = VI is constant
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Rearranging: I = P/V. Higher voltage means the denominator increases, so current decreases. This is why power transmission uses high voltage — to reduce current and losses.
distractors: Voltage and current are independent of power
Current increases with voltage for constant power

toLevel3.question: A USB charger outputs 5 V at 2.4 A. What power does it deliver?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: P = VI = 5 × 2.4 = 12 W. This is typical for a tablet charger.

toLevel3.question: Two devices have the same power rating of 100 W. Device A operates at 10 V, Device B at 100 V. Compare their currents.
toLevel3.correctAnswer: Device A draws 10 A; Device B draws 1 A
toLevel3.correctExplanation: A: I = 100/10 = 10 A. B: I = 100/100 = 1 A. Higher voltage means less current for the same power.
distractors: Current cannot be determined from this information

toLevel3.question: What voltage is required to deliver 500 W of power at a current of 2.5 A?
For a fixed power output, increasing voltage [[decreases]] the required current.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: From I = P/V, for constant P, increasing V reduces I. This inverse relationship is the basis for high-voltage power transmission.

toLevel3.question: A household circuit with a 10 A fuse at 240 V can safely deliver a maximum power of [[2400]] W.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Maximum P = VI = 240 × 10 = 2400 W. Any load exceeding this will blow the 10 A fuse.

toLevel3.question: The formula P = VI can be derived by combining P = E/t with V = E/Q and I = [[Q/t]].
toLevel3.correctExplanation: P = E/t, V = E/Q gives E = VQ, so P = VQ/t = V × (Q/t) = V × I = VI. The current formula I = Q/t completes the derivation.

toLevel3.question: A 240 V, 60 W light bulb draws the same current as a 120 V, 60 W light bulb.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: At 240 V: I = 60/240 = 0.25 A. At 120 V: I = 60/120 = 0.5 A. The lower voltage bulb needs twice the current for the same power.

toLevel4.question: A circuit has a 9 V battery and three identical resistors in series. If the total current is 0.3 A, what power is dissipated by each resistor?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Total power = VI = 9 × 0.3 = 2.7 W. With three identical resistors sharing equally: 2.7/3 = 0.9 W each. Or: each has 3 V across it, P = 3 × 0.3 = 0.9 W.

toLevel4.question: A student connects a 6 V, 12 W lamp to a 12 V supply. Assuming resistance stays constant, what power does the lamp actually dissipate?
toLevel4.correctAnswer: 48 W — the lamp will likely burn out
toLevel4.correctExplanation: At 6 V: R = V²/P = 36/12 = 3 Ω. At 12 V: P = V²/R = 144/3 = 48 W. This is four times the rated power — the lamp will blow.
distractors: 24 W — double the voltage means double the power

toLevel4.question: A kettle rated at 2000 W, 240 V has its supply voltage reduced to 200 V. What is the new power output?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: R = V²/P = 240²/2000 = 28.8 Ω. At 200 V: P = 200²/28.8 = 40000/28.8 ≈ 1389 W. Lower voltage significantly reduces power.

toLevel4.question: Three appliances draw 3 A, 5 A, and 8 A respectively from a 240 V supply. What is the total power consumption?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Total current = 3 + 5 + 8 = 16 A. Total P = VI = 240 × 16 = 3840 W. Or calculate each separately: 720 + 1200 + 1920 = 3840 W.

toLevel4.question: An electric car motor operates at 400 V and produces 150 kW of mechanical power at 90% efficiency. What current does it draw from the battery?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Electrical input power = 150,000/0.9 = 166,667 W. Current = P/V = 166,667/400 ≈ 417 A. The motor draws more electrical power than it outputs mechanically due to losses.

toLevel4.question: A power supply provides 48 V and can deliver a maximum of 20 A. What is the maximum power it can provide, and how many 200 W devices can it run?
toLevel4.correctAnswer: 960 W maximum; can run 4 devices (800 W total)
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Max P = VI = 48 × 20 = 960 W. Each device needs 200 W, so 960/200 = 4.8. Only 4 complete devices can be powered (800 W < 960 W).

toLevel4.question: In a voltage divider circuit, a 12 V supply has two equal resistors. The voltage across one resistor is 6 V and the current is 0.1 A. Verify the power using P = VI for each resistor and the total circuit.
toLevel4.correctAnswer: Each resistor: P = 6 × 0.1 = 0.6 W; Total = 1.2 W; this equals P = 12 × 0.1 = 1.2 W for the whole circuit
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Power is conserved: the sum of power in individual components equals total power from the supply. 0.6 + 0.6 = 1.2 W = 12 × 0.1 W.
distractors: Powers cannot be added in series

toLevel4.question: When connecting a device rated for a lower voltage to a higher voltage supply, the power increases with the [[square]] of the voltage ratio.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Since resistance is constant, P = V²/R. Doubling the voltage quadruples the power. This is why correct voltage matching is critical.

toLevel4.question: The maximum power a circuit can safely deliver is determined by the fuse rating multiplied by the [[supply voltage]].
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Maximum P = V × I_fuse. For a 10 A fuse at 240 V, maximum power = 240 × 10 = 2400 W. Exceeding this blows the fuse.

toLevel4.question: In a series circuit, the sum of power dissipated by all components equals the total power [[supplied]] by the battery.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Energy conservation requires that all power provided by the source is accounted for in the components. P_total = P₁ + P₂ + ... = V_supply × I.

toLevel5.question: Analyse why P = VI is more fundamental than P = I²R or P = V²/R, and when each form is most useful.
toLevel5.correctAnswer: P = VI applies universally; P = I²R is useful when current and resistance are known; P = V²/R when voltage and resistance are known
toLevel5.correctExplanation: P = VI is derived directly from energy principles. The other forms substitute Ohm's law (V = IR) into P = VI. P = I²R highlights current's role in heating; P = V²/R shows voltage's effect on power.
distractors: All three forms are equally fundamental
P = I²R is the most fundamental
P = V²/R is only valid for AC circuits

toLevel5.question: A transmission line delivers 1 MW over 100 km. Compare power losses at 240 V versus 240 kV if the line resistance is 10 Ω.
toLevel5.correctAnswer: At 240 V: I = 4167 A, loss = 174 MW (impossible); At 240 kV: I = 4.17 A, loss = 174 W — high voltage is essential
toLevel5.correctExplanation: At low voltage, required current is enormous and I²R losses exceed the power being transmitted. At high voltage, current is tiny and losses are negligible. This demonstrates why power grids use high voltage.
distractors: Losses are the same at both voltages
Losses depend only on distance, not voltage

toLevel5.question: For AC circuits, P = VI gives apparent power (VA), not real power (W). Analyse why the distinction matters.
toLevel5.correctAnswer: In AC with reactive loads, voltage and current can be out of phase; real power = VI × cos(φ) where φ is the phase angle
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Reactive components (capacitors, inductors) cause current and voltage to be out of phase. Real power (useful work) = VI cos(φ). Apparent power (VI) overestimates actual power delivery.
distractors: There is no distinction — P = VI always gives real power
Apparent power is always greater than real power
Phase angle only affects DC circuits

toLevel5.question: Evaluate the maximum power transfer theorem: a source with internal resistance r delivers maximum power to a load when R_load = r. Why is this not the condition for maximum efficiency?
toLevel5.correctAnswer: At R_load = r, half the power is wasted in the source; maximum efficiency requires R_load >> r
toLevel5.correctExplanation: When R_load = r, power splits equally between source and load (50% efficiency). Increasing R_load reduces total power but a larger fraction goes to the load. Maximum efficiency approaches 100% as R_load → ∞.
distractors: Maximum power and maximum efficiency occur at the same load
Efficiency is always 100% regardless of load
Internal resistance has no effect on efficiency

toLevel5.question: A variable speed drive controls a motor by varying both voltage and frequency. Analyse how this affects power consumption compared to running at full speed and using a throttle.
toLevel5.correctAnswer: Variable speed drive adjusts power to match load requirements; throttling wastes energy as heat at the restriction
toLevel5.correctExplanation: P = VI: reducing V and I proportionally reduces input power to match reduced load. Throttling keeps the motor at full power and wastes excess energy, like using a car brake while keeping the accelerator pressed.
distractors: Both methods consume the same total power
Variable speed drives increase power consumption

toLevel5.question: Analyse why a 20 W USB-C charger (5V/3A or 9V/2.2A or 20V/1A) can negotiate different voltage/current combinations.
toLevel5.correctAnswer: All combinations give approximately 20 W (P = VI); higher voltage reduces current, enabling thinner cables
toLevel5.correctExplanation: 5×3 ≈ 9×2.2 ≈ 20×1 ≈ 20 W. The charger negotiates the optimal V/I combination based on the device's needs and cable capability. Higher voltage means lower current and less cable heating.
distractors: Higher voltage always delivers more power
The combinations give different power levels

toLevel5.question: Compare the instantaneous power in a purely resistive AC circuit versus a purely capacitive AC circuit when both have the same V_rms and I_rms.
toLevel5.correctAnswer: Resistive: average power = V_rms × I_rms; Capacitive: average power = 0 because energy oscillates between source and capacitor
toLevel5.correctExplanation: In a resistor, V and I are in phase: power is always positive. In a capacitor, V and I are 90° out of phase: power alternates positive and negative, averaging to zero. No net energy is consumed.
distractors: Both consume the same average power
Instantaneous power is always positive in both

toLevel5.question: Evaluate the relationship between electrical power input and mechanical power output of a motor, considering efficiency and torque-speed characteristics.
toLevel5.correctAnswer: P_mechanical = η × P_electrical = η × VI; as load increases, current increases to maintain torque, increasing electrical power input
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Motor efficiency η relates input to output: P_mech = η × VI. Under load, the motor draws more current to produce more torque (τ = kI). Back-EMF decreases, further increasing current and input power.
distractors: Electrical and mechanical power are always equal
Motors always operate at constant power

toLevel5.question: In AC circuits, the [[power factor]] (cos φ) determines what fraction of apparent power (VA) is real power (W).
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Power factor = cos(phase angle between V and I). A power factor of 1 means all apparent power is real (resistive load). A power factor of 0 means no real power is consumed (purely reactive load).

toLevel5.question: The maximum power transfer theorem states that maximum power is delivered to the load when load resistance equals the [[internal resistance]] of the source.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: When R_load = r_internal, the load receives maximum power (V²/4r). However, efficiency is only 50% at this point.
